description: Back-formation from chamfering, from Middle French chanfrain, from Middle French, Old French chanfraindre, possibly a compound of chant (“corner”), from Latin canthus (of either Celtic or Latin origin) + fraindre (“to break”), from frangō (“I break”).

entries.meaning: An obtuse-angled relief or cut at an edge added for a finished appearance and to break sharp edges.

verbs.description: chamfer (third-person singular simple present chamfers, present participle chamfering, simple past and past participle chamfered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cut off the edge or corner of something.
(transitive) To cut a groove in something.
